facts.text: The case is titled Criminal Appeal No. 129 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 129 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 9, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 697 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 9, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 697 of 1959.

facts.text: Naunit Lal appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Naunit Lal, for the appellant.

facts.text: C. Mathur and C. P. Lal appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: C. Mathur and C. P. Lal, for the respondent.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 5, 1961 by Sarkar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-

facts.text: The appellant had earlier left India.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who had earlier left India,

facts.text: Appellant returned to India on a passport granted by the Government of Pakistan on May 16, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: returned on a passport granted by the Government of Pakistan on May 16, 1953.

facts.text: Visa endorsed on appellant's passport by Indian authorities permitting stay in India for three months, later extended up to November 15, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: He had a visa endorsed on his passport by the Indian authorities permitting him to stay in India for three months and this permission was later extended upto November 15, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant did not return to Pakistan within November 15, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: He did number, however, return to Pakistan within that date

facts.text: Appellant convicted under section 14 of the Foreigners Act, 1946 by Sub-Divisional Magistrate on March 14, 1959 and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year.

anchor.surface_text: upon which he was companyvicted under s. 14 of the Foreigners Act,, 1946, by a Sub-Divisional Magistrate on March 14, 1959, and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year.

facts.text: Appellant's appeal to Sessions Judge was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: His appeal to a Sessions Judge was dismissed

facts.text: Allahabad High Court refused to interfere with Sessions Judge's order in revision.

anchor.surface_text: and the High Court at Allahabad, on being moved in revision, refused to interfere with the order of the Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Appellant convicted for breach of paragraph 7 of the Foreigners Order of 1948 issued under section 3 of the Foreigners Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had been companyvicted for breach of paragraph 7 of the Foreigners Order of 1948, issued under s. 3 of the Foreigners Act.

facts.text: Visa on appellant's passport showed permission to stay till November 15, 1953 but he stayed after that date.

anchor.surface_text: As earlier stated, the visa on the appellants passport showed that he had permission to stay in India till November 15, 1953 but he stayed on after that date.

facts.text: Appellant contended that paragraph 7 applies only to a foreigner on the date of entry into India.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended on behalf of the appellant that he companyld number be companyvicted of a breach of paragraph 7 of the Foreigners Order for that paragraph applies to a foreigner entering India on the authority of a visa issued in pursuance of the Indian Passport Act and overstaying the period for which he is permitted to stay in India.

facts.text: Appellant claimed he was not a foreigner on the date of his entry into India.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended that the foreigner companytemplated in this paragraph is a person who was a foreigner on the date of his entry into India. The appellant says that on that date he was number a foreigner

facts.text: Appellant was born at Allahabad at a time when it was within His Britannic Majesty's Dominion.

anchor.surface_text: That the appellant was born at Allahabad at a time when it was within his Britannic Majestys Dominion is number in dispute.

facts.text: Appellant was a natural-born British subject as defined in section 1(1)(a) of the British Nationality and Status of Aliens Act, 1914.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, we think that it must be held that the date of his entry into India the appellant was a natural-born British subject and, therefore, number a foreigner.

facts.text: Appellant was not a foreigner under the definition in section 2(a) of the Foreigners Act as it stood in 1953.

anchor.surface_text: That definition has changed from time to time, but we are companycerned with the definition as it stood in 1953 when the appellant entered India,

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside the conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the companyviction of the appellant and sentence passed on him.

facts.text: Definition of foreigner in Foreigners Act amended with effect from January 19, 1957 by Act 11 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The definition of a foreigner in the Foreigners Act was amended with effect from January 19,1957, by Act 11 of 1957.

facts.text: Amended definition of foreigner is a person who is not a citizen of India.

anchor.surface_text: The definition since that date is as follows foreigner means a person who is number a citizen of India.

facts.text: Court made no finding on the effect of the amended definition on the appellant's status.

anchor.surface_text: We wish to make it clear that we have said numberhing as to the effect of the amended definition of a foreigner on the status of the appellant. No question as to the effect of the amended definition on the appellants status fell for our decision in this case

anchor.surface_text: The word foreigner is defined in that Act in s. 2 a . That definition has changed from time to time, but we are concerned with the definition as it stood in 1953 when the appellant entered India, which was in these terms foreigner means a person who  1  is not a natural-born British subject as defined in sub-sections  1  and  2  of Section I of the British Nationality and Status of Aliens Act, 1914, or  2  has not been granted a certificate of naturalisation as a British subject under any law for the time being in force in British India, or  3  is not a citizen of India.

concepts.interpretation: Definition as it stood in 1953 applies; word 'foreigner' in para 7 has same meaning as in the Act; appellant fell within clause 1 as natural-born British subject.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 9, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 697 of 1959.

issues.text: Whether paragraph 7 of the Foreigners Order of 1948 applies to a person who was not a foreigner on the date of entry into India?

anchor.surface_text: It is contended on behalf of the appellant that he could not be convicted of a breach of paragraph 7 of the Foreigners Order for that paragraph applies to a foreigner entering India on the authority of a visa issued in pursuance of the Indian Passport Act and overstaying the period for which he is permitted to stay in India. It is

issues.text: Whether the word 'foreigner' in paragraph 7 of the Foreigners Order has the same meaning as in the Foreigners Act?

anchor.surface_text: This contention of the appellant is plainly correct. The paragraph contemplates a foreigner entering India, and therefore, a person who at the date of the entry was a foreigner. Now, the word foreigner in paragraph 7 has the same meaning as that word has in the Foreigners Act.

issues.text: Whether the appellant was a natural-born British subject as defined in sub-sections (1) and (2) of Section 1 of the British Nationality and Status of Aliens Act, 1914?

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contention is that he was not a foreigner because he came within cl. 1 of the definition as he was a natural-born British subject within s. 1(1), a of the British Nationality and Status of Aliens Act, 1914. Now that provision is in these terms

issues.text: Whether the appellant was a 'foreigner' within the meaning of Section 2(a) of the Foreigners Act as it stood in 1953?

anchor.surface_text: That definition has changed from time to time, but we are concerned with the definition as it stood in 1953 when the appellant entered India, which was in these terms foreigner means a person who 1 is not a natural-born British subject as defined in sub-sections 1 and 2 of Section I of the British Nationality

issues.text: What is the effect of the amended definition of 'foreigner' under Act 11 of 1957 on the status of the appellant?

anchor.surface_text: We wish to make it clear that we have said nothing as to the effect of the amended definition of a foreigner on the status of the appellant. No question as to the effect of the amended definition on the appellants status fell for our decision in this case for we were only concerned with his status in 1953.

holdings.text: This contention of the appellant is plainly correct. The paragraph contemplates a foreigner entering India, and therefore, a person who at the date of the entry was a foreigner.

anchor.surface_text: This contention of the appellant is plainly correct. The paragraph contemplates a foreigner entering India, and therefore, a person who at the date of the entry was a foreigner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court agrees with appellant's textual reading that para 7 targets foreigners at time of entry on visa.

holdings.text: Now, the word foreigner in paragraph 7 has the same meaning as that word has in the Foreigners Act.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the word foreigner in paragraph 7 has the same meaning as that word has in the Foreigners Act. The word foreigner is defined in that Act in s. 2 a .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction: term in Order issued under Act takes Act's definition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Birth in Allahabad under British dominion fits s.1(1)(a) of 1914 Act; thus within cl.1 of 1953 definition excluding from 'foreigner'.

holdings.text: He could not have committed a breach of paragraph 7 of the Foreigners Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since not foreigner at entry, para 7 obligations do not apply; no violation.
